column2: A TALE OF THE RAGGED MOUNTAINS
column3: A TALE OF THE RAGGED MOUNTAINS

column2: DURING the fall of the year 1827, while residing near Charlottesville, Virginia, I casually made the acquaintance of Mr. Augustus Bedloe.
column3: DURING the fall of the year eighteen twenty seven, while residing near Charlottesville, Virginia, I casually made the acquaintance of mr Augustus Bedloe.

column2: This young gentleman was remarkable in every respect, and excited in me a profound interest and curiosity.
column3: This young gentleman was remarkable in every respect, and excited in me a profound interest and curiosity.

column2: I found it impossible to comprehend him either in his moral or his physical relations.
column3: I found it impossible to comprehend him either in his moral or his physical relations.

column2: Of his family I could obtain no satisfactory account.
column3: Of his family I could obtain no satisfactory account.

column2: Whence he came, I never ascertained. Even about his age--although I call him a young gentleman--there was something which perplexed me in no little degree.
column3: Whence he came, I never ascertained. Even about his age-although I call him a young gentleman-there was something which perplexed me in no little degree.

column2: He certainly seemed young--and he made a point of speaking about his youth--yet there were moments when I should have had little trouble in imagining him a hundred years of age.
column3: He certainly seemed young-and he made a point of speaking about his youth-yet there were moments when I should have had little trouble in imagining him a hundred years of age.

column2: But in no regard was he more peculiar than in his personal appearance.
column3: But in no regard was he more peculiar than in his personal appearance.

column2: He was singularly tall and thin.
column3: He was singularly tall and thin.

column2: He stooped much.
column3: He stooped much.

column2: His limbs were exceedingly long and emaciated.
column3: His limbs were exceedingly long and emaciated.

column2: His forehead was broad and low.
column3: His forehead was broad and low.

column2: His complexion was absolutely bloodless.
column3: His complexion was absolutely bloodless.

column2: His mouth was large and flexible, and his teeth were more wildly uneven, although sound, than I had ever before seen teeth in a human head.
column3: His mouth was large and flexible, and his teeth were more wildly uneven, although sound, than I had ever before seen teeth in a human head.

column2: The expression of his smile, however, was by no means unpleasing, as might be supposed; but it had no variation whatever.
column3: The expression of his smile, however, was by no means unpleasing, as might be supposed; but it had no variation whatever.

column2: It was one of profound melancholy--of a phaseless and unceasing gloom.
column3: It was one of profound melancholy-of a phaseless and unceasing gloom.

column2: His eyes were abnormally large, and round like those of a cat.
column3: His eyes were abnormally large, and round like those of a cat.

column2: The pupils, too, upon any accession or diminution of light, underwent contraction or dilation, just such as is observed in the feline tribe.
column3: The pupils, too, upon any accession or diminution of light, underwent contraction or dilation, just such as is observed in the feline tribe.

column2: In moments of excitement the orbs grew bright to a degree almost inconceivable; seeming to emit luminous rays, not of a reflected but of an intrinsic lustre, as does a candle or the sun; yet their ordinary condition was so totally vapid, filmy, and dull as to convey the idea of the eyes of a long-interred corpse.
column3: In moments of excitement the orbs grew bright to a degree almost inconceivable; seeming to emit luminous rays, not of a reflected but of an intrinsic lustre, as does a candle or the sun; yet their ordinary condition was so totally vapid, filmy, and dull as to convey the idea of the eyes of a long interred corpse.

column2: These peculiarities of person appeared to cause him much annoyance, and he was continually alluding to them in a sort of half explanatory, half apologetic strain, which, when I first heard it, impressed me very painfully.
column3: These peculiarities of person appeared to cause him much annoyance, and he was continually alluding to them in a sort of half explanatory, half apologetic strain, which, when I first heard it, impressed me very painfully.

column2: I soon, however, grew accustomed to it, and my uneasiness wore off.
column3: I soon, however, grew accustomed to it, and my uneasiness wore off.

column2: It seemed to be his design rather to insinuate than directly to assert that, physically, he had not always been what he was--that a long series of neuralgic attacks had reduced him from a condition of more than usual personal beauty, to that which I saw.
column3: It seemed to be his design rather to insinuate than directly to assert that, physically, he had not always been what he was-that a long series of neuralgic attacks had reduced him from a condition of more than usual personal beauty, to that which I saw.

column2: For many years past he had been attended by a physician, named Templeton--an old gentleman, perhaps seventy years of age--whom he had first encountered at Saratoga, and from whose attention, while there, he either received, or fancied that he received, great benefit.
column3: For many years past he had been attended by a physician, named Templeton-an old gentleman, perhaps seventy years of age-whom he had first encountered at Saratoga, and from whose attention, while there, he either received, or fancied that he received, great benefit.

column2: The result was that Bedloe, who was wealthy, had made an arrangement with Dr. Templeton, by which the latter, in consideration of a liberal annual allowance, had consented to devote his time and medical experience exclusively to the care of the invalid.
column3: The result was that Bedloe, who was wealthy, had made an arrangement with dr Templeton, by which the latter, in consideration of a liberal annual allowance, had consented to devote his time and medical experience exclusively to the care of the invalid.

column2: Doctor Templeton had been a traveller in his younger days, and at Paris had become a convert, in great measure, to the doctrines of Mesmer.
column3: Doctor Templeton had been a traveller in his younger days, and at Paris had become a convert, in great measure, to the doctrines of Mesmer.

column2: It was altogether by means of magnetic remedies that he had succeeded in alleviating the acute pains of his patient; and this success had very naturally inspired the latter with a certain degree of confidence in the opinions from which the remedies had been educed.
column3: It was altogether by means of magnetic remedies that he had succeeded in alleviating the acute pains of his patient; and this success had very naturally inspired the latter with a certain degree of confidence in the opinions from which the remedies had been educed.

column2: The Doctor, however, like all enthusiasts, had struggled hard to make a thorough convert of his pupil, and finally so far gained his point as to induce the sufferer to submit to numerous experiments.
column3: The Doctor, however, like all enthusiasts, had struggled hard to make a thorough convert of his pupil, and finally so far gained his point as to induce the sufferer to submit to numerous experiments.

column2: By a frequent repetition of these, a result had arisen, which of late days has become so common as to attract little or no attention, but which, at the period of which I write, had very rarely been known in America.
column3: By a frequent repetition of these, a result had arisen, which of late days has become so common as to attract little or no attention, but which, at the period of which I write, had very rarely been known in America.

column2: I mean to say, that between Doctor Templeton and Bedloe there had grown up, little by little, a very distinct and strongly marked rapport, or magnetic relation.
column3: I mean to say, that between Doctor Templeton and Bedloe there had grown up, little by little, a very distinct and strongly marked rapport, or magnetic relation.

column2: I am not prepared to assert, however, that this rapport extended beyond the limits of the simple sleep-producing power, but this power itself had attained great intensity.
column3: I am not prepared to assert, however, that this rapport extended beyond the limits of the simple sleep producing power, but this power itself had attained great intensity.

column2: At the first attempt to induce the magnetic somnolency, the mesmerist entirely failed.
column3: At the first attempt to induce the magnetic somnolency, the mesmerist entirely failed.

column2: In the fifth or sixth he succeeded very partially, and after long continued effort.
column3: In the fifth or sixth he succeeded very partially, and after long continued effort.

column2: Only at the twelfth was the triumph complete.
column3: Only at the twelfth was the triumph complete.

column2: After this the will of the patient succumbed rapidly to that of the physician, so that, when I first became acquainted with the two, sleep was brought about almost instantaneously by the mere volition of the operator, even when the invalid was unaware of his presence.
column3: After this the will of the patient succumbed rapidly to that of the physician, so that, when I first became acquainted with the two, sleep was brought about almost instantaneously by the mere volition of the operator, even when the invalid was unaware of his presence.

column2: It is only now, in the year 1845, when similar miracles are witnessed daily by thousands, that I dare venture to record this apparent impossibility as a matter of serious fact.
column3: It is only now, in the year eighteen forty five, when similar miracles are witnessed daily by thousands, that I dare venture to record this apparent impossibility as a matter of serious fact.

column2: The temperature of Bedloe was, in the highest degree sensitive, excitable, enthusiastic.
column3: The temperature of Bedloe was, in the highest degree sensitive, excitable, enthusiastic.

column2: His imagination was singularly vigorous and creative; and no doubt it derived additional force from the habitual use of morphine, which he swallowed in great quantity, and without which he would have found it impossible to exist.
column3: His imagination was singularly vigorous and creative; and no doubt it derived additional force from the habitual use of morphine, which he swallowed in great quantity, and without which he would have found it impossible to exist.

column2: It was his practice to take a very large dose of it immediately after breakfast each morning--or, rather, immediately after a cup of strong coffee, for he ate nothing in the forenoon--and then set forth alone, or attended only by a dog, upon a long ramble among the chain of wild and dreary hills that lie westward and southward of Charlottesville, and are there dignified by the title of the Ragged Mountains.
column3: It was his practice to take a very large dose of it immediately after breakfast each morning-or, rather, immediately after a cup of strong coffee, for he ate nothing in the forenoon-and then set forth alone, or attended only by a dog, upon a long ramble among the chain of wild and dreary hills that lie westward and southward of Charlottesville, and are there dignified by the title of the Ragged Mountains.

column2: Upon a dim, warm, misty day, toward the close of November, and during the strange interregnum of the seasons which in America is termed the Indian Summer, Mr. Bedloe departed as usual for the hills.
column3: Upon a dim, warm, misty day, toward the close of November, and during the strange interregnum of the seasons which in America is termed the Indian Summer, mr Bedloe departed as usual for the hills.

column2: The day passed, and still he did not return.
column3: The day passed, and still he did not return.

column2: About eight o'clock at night, having become seriously alarmed at his protracted absence, we were about setting out in search of him, when he unexpectedly made his appearance, in health no worse than usual, and in rather more than ordinary spirits.
column3: About eight o'clock at night, having become seriously alarmed at his protracted absence, we were about setting out in search of him, when he unexpectedly made his appearance, in health no worse than usual, and in rather more than ordinary spirits.

column2: The account which he gave of his expedition, and of the events which had detained him, was a singular one indeed.
column3: The account which he gave of his expedition, and of the events which had detained him, was a singular one indeed.

column2: You will remember, said he, "that it was about nine in the morning when I left Charlottesville.
column3: You will remember, said he, "that it was about nine in the morning when I left Charlottesville.

column2: I bent my steps immediately to the mountains, and, about ten, entered a gorge which was entirely new to me.
column3: I bent my steps immediately to the mountains, and, about ten, entered a gorge which was entirely new to me.

column2: I followed the windings of this pass with much interest.
column3: I followed the windings of this pass with much interest.

column2: The scenery which presented itself on all sides, although scarcely entitled to be called grand, had about it an indescribable and to me a delicious aspect of dreary desolation.
column3: The scenery which presented itself on all sides, although scarcely entitled to be called grand, had about it an indescribable and to me a delicious aspect of dreary desolation.

column2: The solitude seemed absolutely virgin.
column3: The solitude seemed absolutely virgin.

column2: I could not help believing that the green sods and the gray rocks upon which I trod had been trodden never before by the foot of a human being.
column3: I could not help believing that the green sods and the gray rocks upon which I trod had been trodden never before by the foot of a human being.

column2: So entirely secluded, and in fact inaccessible, except through a series of accidents, is the entrance of the ravine, that it is by no means impossible that I was indeed the first adventurer--the very first and sole adventurer who had ever penetrated its recesses.
column3: So entirely secluded, and in fact inaccessible, except through a series of accidents, is the entrance of the ravine, that it is by no means impossible that I was indeed the first adventurer-the very first and sole adventurer who had ever penetrated its recesses.

column2: The thick and peculiar mist, or smoke, which distinguishes the Indian Summer, and which now hung heavily over all objects, served, no doubt, to deepen the vague impressions which these objects created.	The thick and peculiar mist, or smoke, which distinguishes the Indian Summer, and which now hung heavily over all objects, served, no doubt, to deepen the vague impressions which these objects created.
column3: true

column2: So dense was this pleasant fog that I could at no time see more than a dozen yards of the path before me.
column3: So dense was this pleasant fog that I could at no time see more than a dozen yards of the path before me.

column2: This path was excessively sinuous, and as the sun could not be seen, I soon lost all idea of the direction in which I journeyed.
column3: This path was excessively sinuous, and as the sun could not be seen, I soon lost all idea of the direction in which I journeyed.

column2: In the meantime the morphine had its customary effect--that of enduing all the external world with an intensity of interest.
column3: In the meantime the morphine had its customary effect-that of enduing all the external world with an intensity of interest.

column2: In the quivering of a leaf--in the hue of a blade of grass--in the shape of a trefoil--in the humming of a bee--in the gleaming of a dew-drop--in the breathing of the wind--in the faint odors that came from the forest--there came a whole universe of suggestion--a gay and motley train of rhapsodical and immethodical thought.
column3: In the quivering of a leaf-in the hue of a blade of grass-in the shape of a trefoil-in the humming of a bee-in the gleaming of a dew drop-in the breathing of the wind-in the faint odors that came from the forest-there came a whole universe of suggestion-a gay and motley train of rhapsodical and immethodical thought.

column2: Busied in this, I walked on for several hours, during which the mist deepened around me to so great an extent that at length I was reduced to an absolute groping of the way.	Busied in this, I walked on for several hours, during which the mist deepened around me to so great an extent that at length I was reduced to an absolute groping of the way.
column3: false

column2: And now an indescribable uneasiness possessed me--a species of nervous hesitation and tremor.
column3: And now an indescribable uneasiness possessed me-a species of nervous hesitation and tremor.

column2: I feared to tread, lest I should be precipitated into some abyss.
column3: I feared to tread, lest I should be precipitated into some abyss.

column2: I remembered, too, strange stories told about these Ragged Hills, and of the uncouth and fierce races of men who tenanted their groves and caverns.
column3: I remembered, too, strange stories told about these Ragged Hills, and of the uncouth and fierce races of men who tenanted their groves and caverns.

column2: A thousand vague fancies oppressed and disconcerted me--fancies the more distressing because vague.
column3: A thousand vague fancies oppressed and disconcerted me-fancies the more distressing because vague.

column2: Very suddenly my attention was arrested by the loud beating of a drum.
column3: Very suddenly my attention was arrested by the loud beating of a drum.

column2: My amazement was, of course, extreme.	My amazement was, of course, extreme.
column3: true

column2: A drum in these hills was a thing unknown.
column3: A drum in these hills was a thing unknown.

column2: I could not have been more surprised at the sound of the trump of the Archangel.
column3: I could not have been more surprised at the sound of the trump of the Archangel.

column2: But a new and still more astounding source of interest and perplexity arose.
column3: But a new and still more astounding source of interest and perplexity arose.

column2: There came a wild rattling or jingling sound, as if of a bunch of large keys, and upon the instant a dusky-visaged and half-naked man rushed past me with a shriek.
column3: There came a wild rattling or jingling sound, as if of a bunch of large keys, and upon the instant a dusky visaged and half naked man rushed past me with a shriek.

column2: He came so close to my person that I felt his hot breath upon my face.
column3: He came so close to my person that I felt his hot breath upon my face.

column2: He bore in one hand an instrument composed of an assemblage of steel rings, and shook them vigorously as he ran.
column3: He bore in one hand an instrument composed of an assemblage of steel rings, and shook them vigorously as he ran.

column2: Scarcely had he disappeared in the mist before, panting after him, with open mouth and glaring eyes, there darted a huge beast.
column3: Scarcely had he disappeared in the mist before, panting after him, with open mouth and glaring eyes, there darted a huge beast.

column2: I could not be mistaken in its character.
column3: I could not be mistaken in its character.

column2: It was a hyena.
column3: It was a hyena.

column2: The sight of this monster rather relieved than heightened my terrors--for I now made sure that I dreamed, and endeavored to arouse myself to waking consciousness.	The sight of this monster rather relieved than heightened my terrors-for I now made sure that I dreamed, and endeavored to arouse myself to waking consciousness.
column3: true

column2: I stepped boldly and briskly forward. I rubbed my eyes.
column3: I stepped boldly and briskly forward. I rubbed my eyes.

column2: I called aloud.
column3: I called aloud.

column2: I pinched my limbs.
column3: I pinched my limbs.

column2: A small spring of water presented itself to my view, and here, stooping, I bathed my hands and my head and neck.
column3: A small spring of water presented itself to my view, and here, stooping, I bathed my hands and my head and neck.

column2: This seemed to dissipate the equivocal sensations which had hitherto annoyed me.
column3: This seemed to dissipate the equivocal sensations which had hitherto annoyed me.

column2: I arose, as I thought, a new man, and proceeded steadily and complacently on my unknown way.
column3: I arose, as I thought, a new man, and proceeded steadily and complacently on my unknown way.

column2: At length, quite overcome by exertion, and by a certain oppressive closeness of the atmosphere, I seated myself beneath a tree.	At length, quite overcome by exertion, and by a certain oppressive closeness of the atmosphere, I seated myself beneath a tree.
column3: false

column2: Presently there came a feeble gleam of sunshine, and the shadow of the leaves of the tree fell faintly but definitely upon the grass.
column3: Presently there came a feeble gleam of sunshine, and the shadow of the leaves of the tree fell faintly but definitely upon the grass.

column2: At this shadow I gazed wonderingly for many minutes.
column3: At this shadow I gazed wonderingly for many minutes.

column2: Its character stupefied me with astonishment.
column3: Its character stupefied me with astonishment.

column2: I looked upward.
column3: I looked upward.

column2: The tree was a palm.
column3: The tree was a palm.

column2: I now arose hurriedly, and in a state of fearful agitation--for the fancy that I dreamed would serve me no longer.	I now arose hurriedly, and in a state of fearful agitation-for the fancy that I dreamed would serve me no longer.
column3: true

column2: I saw--I felt that I had perfect command of my senses--and these senses now brought to my soul a world of novel and singular sensation.
column3: I saw-I felt that I had perfect command of my senses-and these senses now brought to my soul a world of novel and singular sensation.

column2: The heat became all at once intolerable.
column3: The heat became all at once intolerable.

column2: A strange odor loaded the breeze.
column3: A strange odor loaded the breeze.

column2: A low, continuous murmur, like that arising from a full, but gently flowing river, came to my ears, intermingled with the peculiar hum of multitudinous human voices.
column3: A low, continuous murmur, like that arising from a full, but gently flowing river, came to my ears, intermingled with the peculiar hum of multitudinous human voices.

column2: While I listened in an extremity of astonishment which I need not attempt to describe, a strong and brief gust of wind bore off the incumbent fog as if by the wand of an enchanter.	While I listened in an extremity of astonishment which I need not attempt to describe, a strong and brief gust of wind bore off the incumbent fog as if by the wand of an enchanter.
column3: false

column2: I found myself at the foot of a high mountain, and looking down into a vast plain, through which wound a majestic river.	I found myself at the foot of a high mountain, and looking down into a vast plain, through which wound a majestic river.
column3: false

column2: On the margin of this river stood an Eastern-looking city, such as we read of in the Arabian Tales, but of a character even more singular than any there described. From my position, which was far above the level of the town, I could perceive its every nook and corner, as if delineated on a map.
column3: On the margin of this river stood an Eastern looking city, such as we read of in the Arabian Tales, but of a character even more singular than any there described. From my position, which was far above the level of the town, I could perceive its every nook and corner, as if delineated on a map.

column2: The streets seemed innumerable, and crossed each other irregularly in all directions, but were rather long winding alleys than streets, and absolutely swarmed with inhabitants.
column3: The streets seemed innumerable, and crossed each other irregularly in all directions, but were rather long winding alleys than streets, and absolutely swarmed with inhabitants.

column2: The houses were wildly picturesque. On every hand was a wilderness of balconies, of verandas, of minarets, of shrines, and fantastically carved oriels.
column3: The houses were wildly picturesque. On every hand was a wilderness of balconies, of verandas, of minarets, of shrines, and fantastically carved oriels.

column2: Bazaars abounded; and in these were displayed rich wares in infinite variety and profusion--silks, muslins, the most dazzling cutlery, the most magnificent jewels and gems.
column3: Bazaars abounded; and in these were displayed rich wares in infinite variety and profusion-silks, muslins, the most dazzling cutlery, the most magnificent jewels and gems.

column2: Besides these things, were seen, on all sides, banners and palanquins, litters with stately dames close veiled, elephants gorgeously caparisoned, idols grotesquely hewn, drums, banners, and gongs, spears, silver and gilded maces.
column3: Besides these things, were seen, on all sides, banners and palanquins, litters with stately dames close veiled, elephants gorgeously caparisoned, idols grotesquely hewn, drums, banners, and gongs, spears, silver and gilded maces.

column2: And amid the crowd, and the clamor, and the general intricacy and confusion--amid the million of black and yellow men, turbaned and robed, and of flowing beard, there roamed a countless multitude of holy filleted bulls, while vast legions of the filthy but sacred ape clambered, chattering and shrieking, about the cornices of the mosques, or clung to the minarets and oriels.
column3: And amid the crowd, and the clamor, and the general intricacy and confusion-amid the million of black and yellow men, turbaned and robed, and of flowing beard, there roamed a countless multitude of holy filleted bulls, while vast legions of the filthy but sacred ape clambered, chattering and shrieking, about the cornices of the mosques, or clung to the minarets and oriels.

column2: From the swarming streets to the banks of the river, there descended innumerable flights of steps leading to bathing places, while the river itself seemed to force a passage with difficulty through the vast fleets of deeply--burthened ships that far and wide encountered its surface.
column3: From the swarming streets to the banks of the river, there descended innumerable flights of steps leading to bathing places, while the river itself seemed to force a passage with difficulty through the vast fleets of deeply-burthened ships that far and wide encountered its surface.

column2: Beyond the limits of the city arose, in frequent majestic groups, the palm and the cocoa, with other gigantic and weird trees of vast age, and here and there might be seen a field of rice, the thatched hut of a peasant, a tank, a stray temple, a gypsy camp, or a solitary graceful maiden taking her way, with a pitcher upon her head, to the banks of the magnificent river.
column3: Beyond the limits of the city arose, in frequent majestic groups, the palm and the cocoa, with other gigantic and weird trees of vast age, and here and there might be seen a field of rice, the thatched hut of a peasant, a tank, a stray temple, a gypsy camp, or a solitary graceful maiden taking her way, with a pitcher upon her head, to the banks of the magnificent river.

column2: You will say now, of course, that I dreamed; but not so.	You will say now, of course, that I dreamed; but not so.
column3: true

column2: What I saw--what I heard--what I felt--what I thought--had about it nothing of the unmistakable idiosyncrasy of the dream.
column3: What I saw-what I heard-what I felt-what I thought-had about it nothing of the unmistakable idiosyncrasy of the dream.

column2: All was rigorously self-consistent.
column3: All was rigorously self consistent.

column2: At first, doubting that I was really awake, I entered into a series of tests, which soon convinced me that I really was. Now, when one dreams, and, in the dream, suspects that he dreams, the suspicion never fails to confirm itself, and the sleeper is almost immediately aroused.
column3: At first, doubting that I was really awake, I entered into a series of tests, which soon convinced me that I really was. Now, when one dreams, and, in the dream, suspects that he dreams, the suspicion never fails to confirm itself, and the sleeper is almost immediately aroused.

column2: Thus Novalis errs not in saying that 'we are near waking when we dream that we dream.' Had the vision occurred to me as I describe it, without my suspecting it as a dream, then a dream it might absolutely have been, but, occurring as it did, and suspected and tested as it was, I am forced to class it among other phenomena."
column3: Thus Novalis errs not in saying that 'we are near waking when we dream that we dream.' Had the vision occurred to me as I describe it, without my suspecting it as a dream, then a dream it might absolutely have been, but, occurring as it did, and suspected and tested as it was, I am forced to class it among other phenomena."

column2: In this I am not sure that you are wrong, observed Dr. Templeton, "but proceed.
column3: In this I am not sure that you are wrong, observed dr Templeton, "but proceed.

column2: You arose and descended into the city."
column3: You arose and descended into the city."

column2: I arose, continued Bedloe, regarding the Doctor with an air of profound astonishment "I arose, as you say, and descended into the city. On my way I fell in with an immense populace, crowding through every avenue, all in the same direction, and exhibiting in every action the wildest excitement.
column3: I arose, continued Bedloe, regarding the Doctor with an air of profound astonishment "I arose, as you say, and descended into the city. On my way I fell in with an immense populace, crowding through every avenue, all in the same direction, and exhibiting in every action the wildest excitement.

column2: Very suddenly, and by some inconceivable impulse, I became intensely imbued with personal interest in what was going on. I seemed to feel that I had an important part to play, without exactly understanding what it was.
column3: Very suddenly, and by some inconceivable impulse, I became intensely imbued with personal interest in what was going on. I seemed to feel that I had an important part to play, without exactly understanding what it was.

column2: Against the crowd which environed me, however, I experienced a deep sentiment of animosity.
column3: Against the crowd which environed me, however, I experienced a deep sentiment of animosity.

column2: I shrank from amid them, and, swiftly, by a circuitous path, reached and entered the city. Here all was the wildest tumult and contention.
column3: I shrank from amid them, and, swiftly, by a circuitous path, reached and entered the city. Here all was the wildest tumult and contention.

column2: A small party of men, clad in garments half-Indian, half-European, and officered by gentlemen in a uniform partly British, were engaged, at great odds, with the swarming rabble of the alleys.
column3: A small party of men, clad in garments half Indian, half European, and officered by gentlemen in a uniform partly British, were engaged, at great odds, with the swarming rabble of the alleys.

column2: I joined the weaker party, arming myself with the weapons of a fallen officer, and fighting I knew not whom with the nervous ferocity of despair.
column3: I joined the weaker party, arming myself with the weapons of a fallen officer, and fighting I knew not whom with the nervous ferocity of despair.

column2: We were soon overpowered by numbers, and driven to seek refuge in a species of kiosk.
column3: We were soon overpowered by numbers, and driven to seek refuge in a species of kiosk.

column2: Here we barricaded ourselves, and, for the present were secure.
column3: Here we barricaded ourselves, and, for the present were secure.

column2: From a loop-hole near the summit of the kiosk, I perceived a vast crowd, in furious agitation, surrounding and assaulting a gay palace that overhung the river. Presently, from an upper window of this place, there descended an effeminate-looking person, by means of a string made of the turbans of his attendants.
column3: From a loop hole near the summit of the kiosk, I perceived a vast crowd, in furious agitation, surrounding and assaulting a gay palace that overhung the river. Presently, from an upper window of this place, there descended an effeminate looking person, by means of a string made of the turbans of his attendants.

column2: A boat was at hand, in which he escaped to the opposite bank of the river.
column3: A boat was at hand, in which he escaped to the opposite bank of the river.

column2: I spoke a few hurried but energetic words to my companions, and, having succeeded in gaining over a few of them to my purpose made a frantic sally from the kiosk. We rushed amid the crowd that surrounded it.
